entry.title: What’s New in SAP Cloud Identity Access Governance: Q2 2025
entry.content:
Welcome to the Q2 2025 release highlights for SAP Cloud Identity Access Governance (IAG), where we unveil the new features designed to enhance security, streamline access governance, and empower your teams. This quarter’s release brings refined role-based risk controls, seamless system integrations, and powerful in-app analysis tools designed to keep your security posture both robust and agile. Whether you’re aiming to automate provisioning tasks or tighten privileged-access reviews, these updates deliver practical improvements you can implement today. Dive into the details below to see how each enhancement makes your day-to-day access governance faster, smarter, and more reliable.

Mitigation Control Assignment to Business Roles

Mitigation controls can now be assigned directly to Business Roles through the Business Role UI or the Mitigation Assignment application, which includes a new Business Roles–specific category. All assignments are recorded in the audit log, and risk assessments for Business Roles inherit any access-level mitigations.

 

Secure Storage of Reports on a Customer-Owned Document Server

Analyze User Access downloads can now be directed straight to your organization’s Document Management Service (DMS). Each report is stored in accordance with your retention and classification policies, removing the need for manual file handling and keeping sensitive data securely within your content repository. Keep an eye on the roadmap as this feature will be extended to include other report types in future releases.

 

Enhanced Access Analysis App

The Access Analysis detail view now includes a built-in smart filter bar for both Access and Risk lists, letting you search, sort, and filter your dataset without ever leaving the interface. This one-pane experience replaces spreadsheet workarounds and speeds up investigations by keeping all controls at your fingertips.

 

Ariba Integration

Additional Ariba user attributes stored in IdDS are automatically provisioned to newly created Ariba accounts. This capability is available in both standalone Cloud Identity Access Governance and SAP Access Control via Bridge integration for IdDS customers. By sourcing attributes directly from the central IdDS, it eliminates manual updates in Ariba and ensures provisioning remains compliant with corporate standards across systems.

 

Updated Rulesets for Concur & BTP Financial Applications

This release adds new segregation-of-duties rulesets for Concur (Expense, Invoice, Request), SAP S/4HANA and SuccessFactors core transactions, and BTP’s advanced financial-closing processes, so you can detect and manage cross-system risks with greater precision and enforce compliance consistently across your finance and HR applications.

Forward Privileged Access Review Requests

The forward functionality in the Privileged Access Monitoring Report enables PAM administrators to efficiently reassign log-review requests to additional reviewers without altering the current workflow stage. This feature enhances resource flexibility by allowing easy redistribution of reviewer responsibilities while maintaining the integrity of existing review processes.

 

Looking Ahead!

With Q2 2025’s release, SAP Cloud Identity Access Governance continues its march toward more intuitive, integrated, and audit-ready access management. These updates deliver targeted improvements that reduce administrative overhead and bolster compliance. Stay tuned for even more innovations next quarter as we refine workflows and expand capabilities based on your feedback.

For more information, to view detailed feature lists, or to get started with SAP Cloud Identity Access Governance, please visit SAP Cloud Identity Access Governance Product Page and Documentation.

entry.title: Securing Agentic AI Through Threat Modeling at SAP
entry.content:
By Helen Oakley, Senior Director of Software and AI Security, SAP Global Security & Cloud Compliance 

This year, at SAP Sapphire, SAP unveiled its expanded vision for Business AI, introducing a growing network of Joule Agents that work across systems and lines of business. This marks a clear step into the era of Agentic AI – systems that can understand context, take initiative, and drive outcomes autonomously. “SAP combines the world’s most powerful suite of business applications with uniquely rich data and the latest AI innovations to create a flywheel of customer value,” said CEO Christian Klein. While this evolution opens exciting possibilities for automation and productivity, it also introduces a new layer of complexity in how we approach security. Agentic systems challenge traditional safeguards, making it essential to identify and mitigate risks early through tailored threat modeling. 

At its core, threat modeling is about asking the right questions early in the development process, while the system is still being designed and built. Rather than simply looking for bugs or code flaws, it forces us to think through how a system might behave in the real world. What could go wrong if an agent’s goals are manipulated? Could someone poison its memory over time? What if an agent uses a tool in an unintended or unsafe way? How could agent-generated content be used to mislead or overload human decision-makers? What happens when agents collaborate or collide in ways that expose the system to cascading failures or manipulation? 

These are not hypothetical questions. They reflect the real and emerging risks of agentic systems. The OWASP Agentic AI Threats & Mitigations Guide is a valuable resource that brings structure to this thinking. It highlights specific threats such as memory poisoning, cascading hallucinations, privilege compromise, and agent communication poisoning. For teams building these systems, it helps provide a common vocabulary and practical examples to guide threat modeling work. 

To give an example of how threat modeling helps in practice, let’s take the case of goal manipulation – one of the emerging risks identified in the OWASP guide. In agentic systems, attackers don’t necessarily need to exploit traditional software flaws. Instead, they can attempt to influence an agent’s behavior over time by subtly manipulating its objectives. This might happen through indirect prompt injection, compromised data sources, or crafted tool responses. Imagine an agent responsible for prioritizing financial transactions; if adversarial inputs gradually shift its decision logic, it could start approving risky payments outside of the intended policy. In threat modeling exercises, we explore how such scenarios could play out by analyzing how the agent forms and updates its goals, how memory and feedback loops could reinforce undesired behaviors, and how downstream actions might be impacted. This helps define targeted mitigations, such as isolating goal-setting logic from external inputs, monitoring shifts in agent behavior, and adding human validation for sensitive decisions. 

The OWASP Agentic AI Threats & Mitigations Guide provides a helpful reference architecture that illustrates where these types of risks can emerge. The diagram below maps threats to key components in a typical agentic system, making it easier to visualize how threat modeling applies in practice. 

Image Source: OWASP Agentic AI Threats and Mitigations guide, “Threat Model Summary” 

At SAP, threat modeling has long been part of our Secure Software Development and Operations Lifecycle (Secure SDOL), which is certified under ISO 27001. This framework ensures security is built into every phase of the product lifecycle, from design to operations. With Agentic AI, we are expanding our threat modeling approach to address risks that don’t typically appear in traditional application security. This includes analyzing agent memory behavior, reasoning patterns, system autonomy, human interaction points, and the dynamics of multi-agent ecosystems. The focus shifts from identifying static vulnerabilities to understanding how autonomy and learning can lead to unintended behaviors. From there, we define appropriate controls and mitigations to reduce those risks. 

The field of Agentic AI security continues to take shape. Standards like ISO 42001 and regulations such as the EU AI Act are in development, and industry best practices are actively maturing. That’s why collaboration is essential. SAP is contributing to the conversations held with industry groups focused on these challenges, including OWASP GenAI initiatives. We’re not just adopting ideas, we’re helping shape them, working with peers and regulators to advance the state of AI security. Our teams bring deep expertise in both enterprise security and AI systems, offering a perspective that’s helping guide how the broader ecosystem approaches agentic risks. 

Transparency remains central to how SAP approaches product security. As we continue evolving our work with AI, we’re committed to sharing what we learn through resources like the SAP Trust Center. Security is not a one-time effort. It is a continuous process, especially with systems as dynamic as Agentic AI. 

Threat modeling helps us stay ahead of these evolving risks and supports the design of systems that are both capable and safe. As Agentic AI becomes more embedded in enterprise workflows, this kind of proactive thinking becomes essential. 

SAP is proud to contribute to shaping the future of secure AI. By collaborating across the industry and applying deep expertise from our teams, we’re helping advance practical, forward-looking approaches to securing the next generation of intelligent systems.

entry.title: GRC Tuesdays: AI-Powered Fraud Prevention
entry.content:
As we are all (too much) aware, Artificial Intelligence has changed our working habits. Sometimes for the good, such as creating a nice illustration for this blog, but also sometimes to the benefit of the dark force when used with malicious intents.

In the area of fraud, AI-generated deception strategies have become more and more sophisticated.

While confirming during a Teams meeting with the Treasurer that a request for an urgent transfer was legitimate and was previously a sure protection against business email compromise scams, advanced audio and video deepfakes have rendered this earlier failsafe obsolete.

So, should we just give up and all move to just one office location so that you can get in person confirmations on sensitive transactions?

No, of course not.

In this blog, I’d like to discuss how SAP solutions for Governance, Risk, and Compliance can be enhanced with “last mile checks” from Trustpair to catch any fraudulent activity before it’s too late.

 

Building a resilient treasury governance

 

With ninety percent of US companies reporting being targeted by cyber fraud in 2024, and thirty-eight percent targeted by payment fraud more than 10 times over the same period as per Trustpair’s Fraud in the Cyber Era: 2025 Fraud Trends & Insights, this is clearly not an isolated issue and it’s not going away any time soon. And just to put it into perspective, the FBI’s latest Internet Crime Report mentions that business email compromise alone totalled $2,770,151,146 reported losses in 2024...

To combat this scourge, companies are investing in 3 main areas:

 

Training & Awareness

Authorizations

Technology

Training & Awareness and Authorizations are perfect examples of preventative control measures: by reducing the fraud attack surface, companies reduce the likelihood of a fraud succeeding.

But much like phishing attacks, if the sample is large enough and the incentives sufficiently compelling, chances are that business email compromise scams will still succeed. And when you think that findings from the 2025 AFP® Payments Fraud and Control Survey indicate that only 22% of organizations were able to recover 75% or more of the funds lost due to payments fraud in 2024, more proactive measures are needed.

This is where technology plays an important role, in my opinion, to address the remaining gap and moves the needle to earlier detection – before the loss is incurred.

 

Fraud prevention triangle

 

Indeed, what if the treasury employee targeted already has the role and authorization to perform the transaction, had the relevant training and is aware that these types of attacks exist but has been convinced by an advanced deepfake that the request is legitimate and still processes the payment?

This where technology takes the relay and enhances human checks to provide a last dependable defense layer based on 3 angles creating the Fraud Prevention Triangle. This depiction below is not from me so all credit here goes to my colleague Emanuele Fumeo - Finance Solution Advisor at SAP:

 

 

 

Anomaly detection

By screening large volumes of transactional data, SAP Business Integrity Screening helps identify anomalous activity quickly using flexible rule sets and predictive analyses to uncover potential fraud patterns or deviations from policy.

Should the attack follow a known pattern, it would be detected at this stage.

 

Business Partner Screening

Within SAP Business Integrity Screening, a dedicated module enables enterprises across all industries to screen their business partners against lists of denied persons and organizations published by governments and global institutions, thus ensuring their compliance with guidelines, regulations, and legislation.

If the business party involved in the transaction has already been flagged by authorities as being on a sanctioned list for instance, then this second automated step would prevent any further processing.

 

Account Validation

Finally, even if the attack hasn’t been detected and the party seems legitimate, Account Validation – also known as Confirmation of Payee, is the last mile check. It is the ultimate control and here, TrustPair can automatically perform one-time checks for new vendors in SAP Ariba but also continuous monitoring of vendor master data and payment files in the ERP system to detect risks, abnormal amounts and duplicates. Ultimately making the entire process more secure and efficient with a last protection net validating the company identity, but also the bank account ownership against banking sources.

Together, human factor prevention with adequate training, attack surface reduction with relevant authorizations and advanced technology detection can help ensure that even advanced fraudulent attacks are deterred – hence safeguarding the company’s financials.

And this must be done consistently across the end-to-end procure to pay process but also directly embedded within the transactional systems to ensure adequate and timely action.

What about you, how does your company address the AI-powered fraud threat? I look forward to reading your thoughts and comments on this blog.

And if you are interested in learning more about TrustPair’s solutions for SAP and how it applies a 5-layer validation with external sources, smart algorithms and complementary checks to secure the source to pay chain, then have a look Trustpair Payment Fraud Prevention on the SAP Store.

entry.title: Navigating Governance, Risk, and Compliance (GRC) in Today’s Business Environment
entry.content:
In complex regulatory and business environments, organizations are under growing pressure to manage risks, ensure compliance, and uphold strong governance practices. Governance, Risk, and Compliance (GRC) is the strategic framework designed to meet these demands—helping businesses align IT with corporate objectives, manage risk proactively, and ensure compliance across an increasingly complex regulatory landscape.

What is GRC?

Governance, Risk, and Compliance (GRC) is a coordinated strategy for managing an organization's overall governance, enterprise risk management, and compliance with regulations. GRC provides a structured approach to decision-making by integrating risk, compliance, and performance data across departments. When effectively implemented, GRC helps reduce uncertainty, control costs, mitigate IT and security risks, and improve overall business performance.

What’s Driving the Need for GRC Today?

Organizations face big waves in diverse, fast-moving risks—from cybersecurity threats to geopolitical disruptions—creating a need for real-time risk awareness and accountability. At the same time, global regulatory frameworks are becoming more demanding and complex, with increasing expectations around transparency and internal controls.

Digital transformation of businesses introduces both opportunity and risk. Real-time processes, machine learning, robotic process automation (RPA), and increased collaboration across organizational boundaries demand new approaches to monitoring, assurance, and control. Traditional, manual GRC practices are no longer sufficient in this dynamic environment.

GRC and SAP’s Secure Operations Map

In SAP’s Secure Operations Map (SOM), GRC is embedded in four critical domains:

  • Security Governance
  • Risk Management
  • Regulatory Process Compliance
  • Audit & Fraud Management

This integration provides a foundational structure to ensure GRC principles are applied consistently across IT, finance, and operations.

GRC in the Context of the Secure Operations Map (SOM)

Why Do Organizations Need GRC Tools?

Many organizations still manage internal controls and compliance processes manually—using spreadsheets, shared drives, emails, and physical binders. This fragmented approach leads to delays, errors, outdated information, and in some cases, missed control testing. This is especially concerning given the need for CEOs and CFOs to sign off on financial statements under personal liability.

GRC tools centralize and automate these processes, providing:

  • A unified view of internal controls across the enterprise
  • Timely and accurate compliance data
  • Reduced risk of financial misstatements or regulatory breaches
  • Greater efficiency in audits, due diligence, M&A, and IPO processes

The objective is clear: ensure operational consistency, identify irregularities or non-compliance, and build a resilient and trustworthy organization.

Example control - Record-to-Report Process

Implementing a GRC Strategy: Key Steps

1. Define the Purpose and Scope

An effective GRC strategy begins with defining its purpose and scope. Organizations need to determine whether the approach will be applied enterprise-wide or focused on high-risk areas such as finance, IT, or third-party relationships. Objectives such as improving audit readiness, meeting regulatory requirements, and reducing operational risk should be clearly defined from the outset.

2. Establish a Governance Structure

The next step is to establish a governance structure. This involves forming a cross-functional GRC steering committee with representatives from compliance, legal, IT, HR, and business leadership. Responsibility for managing risks, maintaining policies, overseeing controls, and handling reporting must be clearly assigned. A dedicated GRC lead should be appointed to coordinate implementation and ensure consistency across departments.

3. Conduct a Risk and Compliance Assessment

A risk and compliance assessment follows. This assessment identifies internal and external risks, maps relevant regulations such as GDPR, HIPAA, and SOX, and evaluates existing compliance gaps. A risk register is developed to classify risks based on their likelihood and potential impact on the organization.

4. Develop and Document Policies and Controls

With the risks identified, the organization can develop and document appropriate policies and controls. These cover areas such as data protection, access management, and anti-fraud measures. Each risk is linked to corresponding control measures, and responsibilities are assigned using a controls matrix to ensure clear traceability.

5. Select and Deploy a GRC Tool

Selecting and deploying a GRC tool is essential for effective execution. The tool should centralize risk and compliance data, support integration with existing systems such as HR, ERP, and incident reporting platforms, and automate key tasks such as alerts, workflows, and compliance tracking. A pilot rollout helps test the setup in a controlled environment before broader deployment.

6. Train and Communicate

Training and communication play a key role in supporting your GRC framework. Employees receive role-specific training on relevant policies and how to report concerns. Internal awareness efforts help foster a culture of compliance and accountability. Managers are provided with tools such as dashboards to monitor compliance within their teams.

7. Monitor, Audit, and Continuously Improve

To keep the GRC strategy effective, organizations must implement ongoing monitoring, regular audits, and continuous improvement. This involves scheduled control testing, internal audits, and the use of key risk indicators to track changes and emerging issues. Reviewing incidents, near misses, and evolving regulations ensures the GRC framework remains current and effective.

Steps for Implementing a GRC Strategy

Tools for GRC in Hybrid SAP Landscapes: Introducing SAP Risk and Assurance Management (RAM)

SAP’s traditional GRC suite—including Process Control (PC) and Risk Management (RM)—is tightly integrated with on-premise ERP systems. However, in today’s cloud and hybrid environments, their capabilities can be limited.

Enter SAP Risk and Assurance Management (RAM): a modern GRC platform designed for hybrid landscapes, including S/4HANA Cloud (both Public and Private Editions). SAP RAM enables organizations to:

  • Leverage a single platform for multiple use cases across the enterprise
  • Turn GRC from a compliance burden into a strategic differentiator
  • Focus resources on high-impact risks, processes, and regulations
  • Continuously monitor control performance using real-time business data
  • Improve compliance and control effectiveness while reducing operational costs

By automating labor-intensive tasks like control testing, RAM not only enhances assurance quality but also frees up internal audit and compliance teams to focus on what matters most.

Example Process Flow in RAM

Final Thoughts

GRC is no longer just a back-office function—it has become a critical enabler of strategic agility, operational resilience, and trust in the digital age. With a well-defined strategy, clear governance structure, and tools like SAP Risk and Assurance Management, organizations can shift from reactive compliance to proactive risk management and business optimization. As part of this evolution, integrating GRC with security monitoring is essential. Giving responsible teams access to timely and accurate security information strengthens their ability to detect potential threats and respond effectively. Auditing and monitoring tools further enhance this by measuring the success of GRC efforts and highlighting areas for improvement. In the next blog post, we’ll explore how SAP supports real-time security monitoring and auditing—turning insight into action to improve enterprise security and compliance.

entry.title: What’s Next for SAP Access Control 12.0?
entry.content:
What’s Next for SAP Access Control 12.0? This is one of the common questions to most of the Organizations, Leaders, IT Directors, Managers, SMEs, Consultants and Vendors who are currently using IAM solution - SAP Access Control 12.0 on any Data Base (Non-HANA DB or HANA DB).

First let’s explore the possible applicable scenarios of the Organizations who are using SAP GRC Access Control 12.0 solution.

  1. Hub Model on HANA DB: SAP GRC Access Control 12.0 on standalone SAP NetWeaver system on HANA Database, connected side-by-side with SAP S/4HANA, ECC, ECP, SuccessFactors or other ABAP systems.
  2. Hub Model on Non-HANA DB: SAP GRC Access Control 12.0 on standalone SAP NetWeaver system on Oracle, MYSQL or another non-HANA database and connected side-by-side with SAP S/4HANA, ECC, SAP ECP, SuccessFactors or other ABAP systems.
  3. Embedded Model on HANA DB: SAP GRC Access Control 12.0 installed on business systems (SAP S/4HANA or SAP ECC etc.) running on HANA database.
  4. Embedded Model on Non-HANA DB: Embedded Model - SAP GRC Access Control 12.0 installed on business systems (SAP ECC, etc.) running on a non-HANA database.

As SAP continues its strategic pivot toward cloud-first solutions, many Organizations using On-Prem SAP Access Control are asking: What’s next? With SAP Access Control 12.0 nearing the end of its innovation cycle and the emergence of new GRC platforms, it’s time to evaluate the future roadmap and available options.

SAP has announced that it will sunset innovation for GRC 12.0, however SAP Access Control and GRC solutions for SAP are NOT end-of-life! SAP is actively developing a next-generation GRC platform: SAP GRC Edition for SAP HANA, expected in Q1 2026. Along with SAP also has cloud-based product called SAP Cloud Identity Access Governance (IAG).

Also, the existing SAP Access Control 12.0 mainstream support ends by 2027 and extended support ends by 2030.

For more information, refer to SAP Product Availability Matrix

For compatibility of SAP Access Control 12.0 with all the target on-premise SAP Applications, please refer to KBA: 1352498 - Support Pack Numbering - GRC Access Control

Now let’s explore the possible upgrade/migrate/future roadmap options in SAP for existing Organizations who are using SAP Access Control 12.0 solution.

Option 1: Upgrade to SAP GRC for HANA 2026

SAP GRC for HANA 2026 is a new version (not a new product) for any SAP GRC on HANA Organizations. This 2026 release is planned for both on-premises and private cloud deployments. Organizations wanting to stay on-prem or private cloud with long-term GRC needs and have existing /future needs of other SAP GRC modules like SAP Process Control or SAP Risk Management can upgrade to this.

Image Source: SAP

For more information, refer to

  1. SAP GRC FOR HANA, 2026* (*current working title)
  2. Understanding SAP’s Product Strategy for Governance, Risk, and Compliance (GRC) Solutions

SAP GRC for HANA 2026 requires below 2 prerequisites

  • SAP NetWeaver should be minimum SAP S/4HANA Foundation. S/4HANA Foundation is just an upgraded version for SAP NetWeaver. This is not SAP S/4HANA full version. Organizations who are using SAP Fiori 2.0 would have already migrated their SAP NetWeaver to SAP S/4HANA Foundation. Incase if you are having lower version of GRC Support pack or still on Fiori 1.0 or using SAP NetWeaver as a base component for SAP GRC, then this is a mandatory step.  In case for an Embedded GRC model, SAP GRC for HANA 2026 can be installed on S4Core.
  • Databased as HANA DB: As HANA 2026 only supports SAP HANA DB, Organizations are forced to migrate their Non-HANA Database to HANA DB.

Organizations can choose the “Hub Model” or “Embedded Model” for their SAP GRC for HANA 2026 upgrade/migration.  In case if an existing Hub Model setup customer wants to move to Embedded model, it is like a new implementation of SAP GRC for HANA 2026 but can reuse existing GRC design.   

How to Migrate to SAP GRC for HANA 2026 from SAP GRC Access Control 12.0?

Once the above prerequisites are complete, SAP Access Control 12.0 can be upgraded to SAP GRC for HANA 2026 release as part of their standard maintenance program, meaning no new SKU or additional purchase is required.

End-of-maintenance (EOM) dates for the 2026 version will be updated to align with HANA EOM dates, extending support until 2040.

Option 2: Migrate to SAP Cloud Identity Access Governance (IAG) – Standard Edition

SAP Cloud Identity Access Governance (IAG), a cloud-based solution designed to manage and govern user access across SAP and non-SAP systems. It's part of SAP’s broader GRC (Governance, Risk, and Compliance) strategy and is hosted on the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP). It can be considered as cloud Access Control in layman terms. It is best for Cloud-first organizations or those adopting SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

This is ideal for the customer who are looking for a standalone cloud governance solution with full lifecycle capabilities.

In case if an existing SAP GRC Access Control 12.0 customer wants to move to Cloud IAG solution, it is like a new implementation of SAP Cloud IAG with reference to existing GRC design.

  • With SAP Cloud IAG Standard Edition, customer can integrate to Cloud system like SAP S/4HANA Public cloud, SAP SuccessFactors, SAP Ariba etc.
  • With Cloud Connector, custom can integrate to On-Prem system like SAP S/4HANA (On-Prem), SAP ECC and other On-Prem systems.

Similar Access Control features, SAP Cloud IAG offers below features:

  • Access Analysis: Real-time insights into user access to detect violations and risks. This is like Access Risk Analysis (ARA).
  • Role Design: Create and optimize business roles for cloud and on-premises systems. This is like Business Role Management (BRM)
  • Access Request: Self-service access provisioning for users across systems. This is like Access Request Management (ARM).
  • Access Certification: Periodic reviews and certifications of user access. This is like User Access Review (UAR) or other certifications reviews.
  • Privileged Access Management: Emergency access handling and monitoring for sensitive operations. This is like Emergency Access Management (EAM).

Will be creating a new blog on “SAP Cloud Identity Access Governance (IAG) with different options, Pros and Cons, possible options”, stay tuned for this.

Option 3: Stay on SAP Access Control 12.0 (Short-Term)

Staying on SAP Access Control 12.0 isn’t a long-term strategy, but it’s a valid short-term option for organizations that need more time to prepare.  As SAP prepares to sunset support for Access Control 12.0 by December 31, 2027 (extended support runs until 2030), many Organizations are evaluating their next move. While cloud-first strategies and the upcoming SAP GRC Edition for HANA (2026) are gaining momentum, some organizations may choose to stay on Access Control 12.0—at least for now so Organizations can get more time for budgeting, complex landscape planning, or team training.

For organizations with complex landscapes, regulatory constraints, or budgetary limitations, staying on Access Control 12.0 offers a stable, compliant, and familiar environment while they prepare for the future. Meanwhile, Organizations can prepare internal teams for the shift to SAP GRC for HANA or SAP Cloud IAG.

In case if an existing SAP GRC Access Control 12.0 customer wants to connect to Cloud systems using Access Control 12.0, SAP Cloud IAG – Integration Edition can be used,

  • SAP Cloud IAG – Integration Edition is a specialized deployment model designed to extend SAP Access Control (on-premise) to manage access governance for cloud applications also like SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Ariba, SAP SuccessFactors etc.
  • It uses the IAG Bridge to connect your existing Access Control system to SAP Cloud IAG, enabling centralized governance across hybrid landscapes.
  • Like SAP Cloud IAG standard edition, SAP Cloud IAG Integration offers Access Control features, however this has limited features than Standard Edition. For example, PAM and Access Certification features are available with Integration Edition. Use IAG Bridge now, then migrate to unified GRC 2026 platform for future-proofing.

#

Scenario

Recommended Solution

Why It Works

1

Long-term on-prem/private-cloud GRC modernization

SAP GRC for HANA 2026

Unified, AI-powered platform; support to 2040

2

Cloud-first strategy (SAP RISE, SuccessFactors, Ariba, etc.)

SAP Cloud IAG – Standard Edition

End-to-end cloud governance with full lifecycle capabilities

3

Using SAP Access Control 12.0. Hybrid landscape with both cloud and on-premises systems

Short-term: IAG Integration Edition
Long-term: GRC for HANA 2026

Leverage current investment, add cloud governance, buy time

Summary

  • Option 1: Upgrade to SAP GRC for HANA 2026
    Ideal for on-premise or private-cloud customers using multiple GRC modules. Also with complex landscape, heavy customization and workflows. Provides a unified, AI-powered platform on SAP HANA with support extended to 2040.
  • Option 2: Migrate to SAP Cloud Identity Access Governance (IAG)
    Suits cloud-first organizations on RISE, S/4HANA Cloud, SuccessFactors, Ariba, or other BTP scenarios. Delivers full lifecycle access governance across SAP and non-SAP systems.
  • Option 3: Stay on SAP Access Control 12.0 (Short-Term)
    Gives organizations extra time for budgeting, complex landscape planning, and team training. Pair Access Control 12.0 with IAG Integration Edition and the IAG Bridge for hybrid visibility.

Conclusion

Choosing the right path from SAP Access Control 12.0 depends on your organization’s strategy, timeline, and risk profile. If you’re committed to on-premise GRC and need long-term stability, upgrading to GRC for HANA 2026 keeps you covered through 2040. For those accelerating cloud adoption, migrating to SAP Cloud IAG delivers a scalable, unified governance experience with less customization options than on-premise. And if you need breathing room to prepare, extending Access Control 12.0 in the short term—combined with IAG Integration—offers continuity without sacrificing compliance.

Whichever route you take, start by mapping your current landscape, aligning stakeholders on priorities, and building a clear project roadmap. Weigh the long-term benefits against immediate constraints to make an informed decision that drives both security and innovation.

entry.title: Compliance in the Age of AI: How SAP GRC’s Regulatory Insights is Redefining Risk Management
entry.content:
Introduction: 

In today’s hyper-regulated environment, where 250+ regulatory change events occur each day, manual compliance processes are no longer sustainable.

Enter: SAP Process Control with Regulatory Insights, a breakthrough SAP GRC innovation built on SAP BTP, powered by AI and Generative AI, that’s helping professionals like Priya flip the compliance narrative from reactive to proactive—and from cost-center to competitive edge.

The Compliance Conundrum: A Modern Enterprise Challenge

Today’s enterprises are dealing with:

  • Constantly evolving regulations (think GDPR, SOX, NIST, COBIT, MaRisk…)
  • Siloed compliance efforts across business units
  • Inconsistent control documentation
  • Audit fatigue
  • Fear of non-compliance fines, loss of reputation, and erosion of stakeholder trust

Manual processes for control mapping, documents handling is error prone, cost intensive, and increases risks, and burnout.

The Game Changer: SAP Process Control with Regulatory Insights

Now let’s zoom into the innovation.

At the heart of this solution lies the SAP Process Control and Regulatory Insights service—on BTP, an AI-powered application designed to interpret, extract, interpret, compare, and map control requirements across evolving regulatory documents.

                                    

 

Let’s break it down through personas in a real-world narrative.

  1. Priya Nair – Chief Compliance Officer

Pain Point: Overwhelmed by frequent regulatory changes
Solution:

With AI-powered Regulatory Insights, Priya’s team can now automatically extract control requirements from large regulatory documents using NLP and machine learning. These are uploaded through the Import Control Requirements App into SAP Process Control.

Impact: Hours of manual reading and interpretation reduced to minutes. Regulations are now available in GRC system as meaningful control definitions.
“It’s like having a legal expert and a data analyst rolled into one AI assistant,” Priya says.

  1. Carlos Menendez – Control Owner in Finance

Pain Point: Updating internal controls with every regulatory change
Solution:

                                        

Using the Manage Control Requirements App, Carlos can quickly create or update internal controls—both centrally and locally—linked to his business processes.

Impact: Faster response to regulatory change. Controls are tracked, assigned, and monitored periodically.
“I no longer rely on spreadsheets and emails—I now have a control cockpit,” Carlos shares.

  1. Jennifer Shen – Internal Auditor

Pain Point: Identifying what changed in a regulation
Solution:

                                    

With Delta Analysis, Jennifer compares two versions of a regulatory framework and instantly sees what’s added, removed, or modified.

Impact: Audit readiness improves drastically. Summary reports help prioritize control updates and decision-making.


“What took days of manual review now takes seconds,” she smiles.

What Frameworks Are Supported?

Currently live within SAP SE environments, the solution supports:

  • C5
  • COBIT
  • FitSM
  • GHB
  • MaRisk
  • NIST
  • SOX

                                       

And this is just a beginning…

What’s Coming Next (Q3–Q4 2025)?

  • Control Gap Analysis – Automatically detect gaps between existing controls and new regulations.

  • Control Coverage Analysis – Suggest additional controls using Gen AI, ensuring better control coverage.

  • Process Orchestration – Enhanced sync between SAP Process Control and Regulatory Insights, helping drive resilience.

Business Benefits: From Cost Center to Strategic Advantage

  • Significant Cost Savings: With ~250 regulatory change events a day, savings range between USD 50K to USD 250K just from automation and reduced manual effort.
  • Audit Readiness: Continuous delta analysis means controls are always audit-ready.
  • Smarter Risk Management: Proactively mitigate non-compliance risks and enhance stakeholder trust.
  • Strategic Focus: Free up experts from mundane tasks—redirect efforts toward innovation and strategic resilience.

Conclusion: Turning Compliance Into Competitive Advantage

In a world where trust is the currency of business, non-compliance is not an option.

SAP Process Control with Regulatory Insights is not just another GRC tool—it’s a strategic partner for organizations that want to stay compliant, agile, and ahead of change.

                                     

                                        

By leveraging AI and Gen AI, it automates the interpretation of complex regulatory language, links it to enterprise controls, and ensures your business is always one step ahead of regulators.

For CCOs like Priya, control owners like Carlos, and auditors like Maya, this is not just about managing risk—it’s about enabling trusted growth.

Key Takeaways

  • Automate regulatory interpretation and control mapping
  • Instantly compare evolving regulations and identify control changes
  • Save costs and man-hours through AI-powered insights
  • Build resilient and audit-ready internal control environments
  • Future-proof compliance strategy with AI-led innovation

Want to see how SAP GRC with Regulatory Insights can transform your compliance posture?
